body_text.text: Learning objectives: To review the MR imaging features of uterine leiomyomas and adenomyosis before and after UAE. To identify preand post-treatment MR imaging features that may be associated with clinical outcome after UAE. Background: UAE is an increasingly performed, minimally invasive alternative to hysterectomy or myomectomy for women with symptomatic uterine fibroids. Clinical failure after UAE for leiomyomas in 6 cases gelatine sponge. Results: The embolization has been effective in 50 cases; in 2 cases of PPH, hysterectomy occurred anyway. We did not have ischemic or embolic, early or late complications.

The full potential of arterial catheterization is being explored for obstetrical conditions such as ectopic pregnancies, abnormalities of the placenta and PPH. Early diagnosis allows for prophylactic, presurgical embolization or placement of catheters or balloons, thus enabling rapid treatment of hemorrhage, should it arise. These cases represent true emergencies; with rapid intervention, the significant morbidity and mortality associated with PPH can become a thing of past.

Imaging diagnosis and transcatheter embolization of acquired uterine vascular malformations A. Picel, S. Koo, A.C. Roberts; Radiology, University of California San Diego, San Diego, CA, United States of America.
Learning objectives: 1. To understand the imaging diagnosis and differences between acquired and congenital uterine arteriovenous malformations.

2. To review the traditional treatment options and the technique of transcatheter arterial embolization. Background: Uterine vascular malformations may present as unexplained vaginal bleeding that can be life-threatening. Acquired vascular malformations are distinct from congenital lesions and may be better classified as arteriovenous fistulas. Transcatheter embolization presents a minimally invasive treatment option that may preserve fertility. Clinical Findings/Procedure: Patients with acquired arteriovenous fistulas often present after uterine trauma or intervention. Imaging diagnosis is important as intervention may worsen bleeding. Color Doppler ultrasound demonstrates a mosaic pattern of turbulent flow with high velocities and low resistive index within hypoechoic spaces. Traditional therapy consists of hysterectomy or ligation of uterine arteries; however, transcatheter arterial embolization provides a less invasive treatment option that has demonstrated success with minimal complications in several case series. Embolic material is commonly administered to provide occlusion. Fertility is usually maintained because of the development of collateral vasculature. Conclusion: 1. Appropriate imaging diagnosis of acquired uterine malformations is important, as surgical intervention may worsen or precipitate life-threatening hemorrhage. 2. Transcatheter arterial embolization offers several advantages over traditional surgical hysterectomy; including a lower risk of complications, fertility preservation, and shorter hospitalization.

Purpose: To assess the feasibility and diagnostic performance of a non-enhanced MR angiography sequence (syngo NATIVE SPACE, Siemens) to detect and quantify lower limb peripheral arterial disease (PAD) with gadolinium-enhanced MR angiography (CE-MRA) as the reference standard. Material and Methods: 51 patients known to have lower limbs arteriopathy were included in this prospective study. We performed in every patient NATIVE sequence and CE-MRA on a 1.5T system. We evaluated exam duration, image quality, and location, number and severity of lesions. Results: Examination duration was longer for NATIVE (mean of 39.6 minutes vs. 10 minutes for CE-MRA). Image quality was significantly better in CE-MRA, with 92% of images listed as good to excellent for CE-MRA and 53% for NATIVE. Sensitivity, specificity, negative predictive value (NPV) and accuracy of NATIVE were, respectively, 75%, 95%, 89% and 88% for all mixed levels, 52%, 97%, 88% and 87% for aorto-iliac level, 87%, 99%, 95%, and 92% for femoro-popliteal level,
C RSE CIRSE Abstract Book intervals using Wilcoxon signed-rank test.

Results: The diameters of three arteries did not significantly change after embolization. The median Vmax of PHA, GDA, and Rt. GEA before embolization were 72.0 cm/sec (range 34. 6-114.7), 52.7 (39.7-102) , and 51. 1 (33.5-69) , respectively. The values 1-2 days after embolization were 44. 6 (22.4-73.4), 55.9 (20.6-84.9) , and 24.2 (9.6-72.3), respectively. Those values 5-7 days after embolization were 51.1 (21.1-111.2) , 57.1 (13.2-111) and 21.7 (7.7-78.2) , respectively. Compared to pre-embolization state, significant decrease in Vmax was observed in 1-2 and 5-7 days after embolization in PHA and Rt.GEA. Conclusion: The Vmax of collateral blood flow to the liver and stomach, from the superior mesenteric artery to PHA and the Rt. GEA via the GDA respectively, continuously decreased in 1-2 and 5-7 days after the embolization. The waiting time longer than 7 days may be necessary for sufficient recovery to pre-embolization state. 20 were under anticoagulation therapy (95%), 8 had both anticoagulation/antiagregant agents (38%) and one patient suffering from severe coagulation disorders. The majority (58%) of hematomas involved the rectus sheath. The bleeding arteries were identified at CT in 13 patients (62%). Active bleeding (extravasation) was seen in 11 patients (55%). The inferior epigastric artery was the site of bleeding and TCE in 13 patients (52%). In 90%, TCE was done with gelfoam and/or coils. Angiographic cessation of bleeding with embolization was achieved in all patients. Complications in 3%. All-cause mortality at 30 days was 35%. Reintroduction of anticoagulant was done in 86%. Conclusion: Drug-induced spontaneous extraperitoneal hematomas are associated with a high mortality rate even the bleeding controlled. TCE is a safe and effective technique in managing patients under anticoagulants.

The significance of right gastric artery anomaly in transarterial hepatic regional therapy S. Sun, S. Laroia, F. Youness, L. Song; Radiology, University of Iowa Hospitals and Clinics, Iowa City, IA, United States of America.

Purpose: To access the incidence and clinical significance of right gastric artery (RGA) arising from left hepatic artery (LHA) deep in the porta hepatis region during transarterial hepatic regional therapy. Material and Methods: Medical records and arteriograms of 560 patients with HCC or hepatic metastases treated either with transarterial bland embolization, TACE, or with radioembolization at our institution from 2003 to 2011 were reviewed and analyzed. The CE-MRA (11 atherosclerotic, 3 dysplastic) with 4 significant RAS. Sensitivity, specificity, PPV and NPV of NE-MRA were, respectively, 100%, 100%, 100% and 100% for reader 1, and 100%, 98,2%, 87,5% and 100% for reader 2. Overestimation of the stenosis grade occurred in two cases for the reader 2 (<50% vs. normal in one case, ≥50% vs. <50% in the other case). Conclusion: NE-MRA has become a viable alternative to CE-MRA for the study of the renal arteries. In case of significant stenosis, given the risk of overestimation, the use of CE-MRA is still indicated.

Variant hepatic arterial anatomy on angiography in 2111 patients A. Polikarpov, P. Tarazov, J. Suvorova, A. Kozlov; Angio/Interventional Radiology, Russian Scientific Center of Radiology and Surgical Technologies, St. Petersburg, Russian Federation.

cite_spans.text: Polikarpov, P. Tarazov, J. Suvorova, A. Kozlov;

body_text.text: Purpose: To study hepatic arterial variants using digital subtraction angiography in a large series of patients. Material and Methods: Hepatic arteriograms of 2111 patients were analyzed according to Hiatt et al. (1994) classification. Results: Six types of arterial anatomy were identified: Type 1.

Typical: the common hepatic artery (CHA) arose from the celiac artery, divided on the gastroduodenal artery (GDA) and the proper hepatic artery (PHA) with the left (LHA) and right (RHA) hepatic arteries = 66.1%. Type 2. Aberrant (replaced or accessory) LHA from the left gastric artery (LGA) = 9.9%. Type 3. Aberrant RHA from the superior mesenteric artery (SMA) = 9.8%. Type 4. Aberrant LHA from

LGA with aberrant RHA from SMA = 3.8%. Type 5. CHA from SMA = 1.7%. Type 6. In 184 (8.7%) remaining cases, 61 other variants were found and divided on 5 groups. Thirty-five variants of the hepatic artery have never been described. Conclusion: Typical arterial anatomy of the liver takes place in about 2/3 patients, while different variants are presented in the remaining 1/3. Knowledge of these variants is important for abdominal surgeons and interventional radiologists.

There are unforeseen consequences that can occur after surgery. A 47-year-old man who developed atypical chest pain after a type A dissection repair. Imaging revealed aortitis and rupture of the aorta into the sternotomy wound.

Primary aorto-esophageal fistula as a complication of an aneurysm of the thoracic aorta dissected A. Ranalli We present a rare case of aorto-esophageal fistula in a patient with aneurysm of the thoracic aorta dissection presented in the emergency department for gastrointestinal hemorrhage. Few cases have been reported in literature. It remains predominantly a postmortem diagnosis.

Endovascular and surgical management of the palatine epithelioid hemangioendothelioma M.S. Olshanskiy 1 , N.G. Korotkih 2 , I.V. Stepanov 2 , V.V. Evteev 3 ; 1 Angiography and Endovascular Surgery, Voronezh Regional Clinical Hospital #1, Voronezh, Russian Federation, 2 Cranio-maxillofacial surgery, Voronezh State Medical Academy, Voronezh, Russian Federation, 3 Radiology, Voronezh Regional Clinical Hospital #1, Voronezh, Russian Federation.

Since 1978 till 2010, approximately 37 cases of rare tumor epithelioid hemangioendothelioma, located in oral cavity, were published in English literature. The case of this tumor affecting hard palatine is unique. A 55-year-old male patient was admitted in cranio-maxillofacial department with the complaints for mass in oral cavity, discomfort during eating, speech roughness and bleeding from ulcerated tumor. Considering a vascular origin of a neoplasm evaluated by ultrasound, CT and angiography it was decided to apply a selective embolotherapy as a fist line therapy. After successful bilateral selective embolization of feeding arteries arising from both external maxillary arteries, this tumor was surgically removed without any sufficient blood loss. In immediate postoperative period, the speech restored and there was no discomfort during eating. The patient was discharged in satisfactory condition on 5 days after this two-line management. The follow-up time consists of 20 months.

Virtual histology-intravascular ultrasound as a diagnostic alternative for morphological characterization of carotid plaque: comparison with histology and high-resolution magnetic resonance findings M. Chiocchi, R. Gandini, M. Stefanini, D. Morosetti, A. Chiaravalloti, G. Loreni, G. Simonetti; Diagnostic Imaging and Interventional Radiology, IRCCS Policlinico di Tor Vergata, Rome, Italy.

cite_spans.text: Gandini, M. Stefanini, D. Morosetti, A. Chiaravalloti, G. Loreni, G. Simonetti;

body_text.text: Learning objectives: The primary target was to validate VH-IVUS as a diagnostic tool for plaque characterization through in vivo characterization of carotid artery plaques by correlation to ex vivo histological specimen. The secondary target was to compare in vivo VH-IVUS with HR-MR imaging. Background: Stroke is the third most common death cause and one of the most common causes of long-term disability in the western world. Carotid plaque morphology is, more than the stenosis degree, the main predictor of cerebro-vascular accidents. Highresolution magnetic resonance imaging demonstrated to be the most sensitive and specific diagnostic tool for in vivo morphological characterization of atheromatous carotid artery plaques, strongly in agreement with histology. VH-IVUS may be a valid diagnostic alternative for the in vivo morphological characterization of carotid artery plaques. Clinical Findings/Procedure: Forty-two images were used for correlation between VH-IVUS and histology. Quantitative analysis of different plaque components revealed a good concordance (0.80) between the two methods (95% CI 0.69 to 0.92). We revealed a strong correlation between data obtained from VH-IVUS evaluation with HR-MR and histological examination. Assessment of necrotic plaque components, however, had non-optimal results using VH-IVUS.

Electronic Posters was similar. Primary patency was not significantly different between the two groups (I: 68%, II: 79%, NS), but assisted primary (I: 73%, II: 89%, NS) and secondary patency (I: 71%, II: 89%, NS) tended to be greater in group II, because of fewer early thrombotic failures. Some 5-mm grafts were used in group I only and with these excluded, the patency differences were minimal, suggesting no benefit to heparin-bonding for grafts > 6 mm. Patencies in both groups were similar to those reported for above-knee ePTFE bypass. Conclusion: Heparin bonding does not improve patency in Viabahn-assisted subintimal recanalization (VASIR) compared to standard Viabahn stent-grafts, making it difficult to justify the added expense, but maintaining patency in a failing graft to allow timely salvage intervention may be an important benefit, particularly in smaller diameter grafts. Patient selection may be a more important predictor of success than heparin bonding.

Sealing antegrade femoral artery puncture sites with a novel bioabsorbable vascular closure device. An analysis of success rates, adverse events and patient satisfaction Purpose: Fast and sufficient vessel leakage sealing after antegrade inguinal arterial access for endovascular intervention is crucial to avoid access site complications and to increase patients' comfort. For a new entirely extravascularly deployed bioabsorbable plugbased vascular closing device (VCD) its feasibility, safety, and pain during implantation was examined. Material and Methods: 59 consecutive patients underwent a peripheral endovascular procedure (PEP) with an antegrade femoral puncture. 42 (73.7%) patients had at least one PEP with common manual compression (MC) in their medical history. The new VCD was used to seal the puncture sites in all cases despite severe calcification. A sonographic check-up of the puncture site was conducted after one day and puncture site bleedings were assessed. After at least one week, the patients were interviewed via telephone for the occurrence of hematomas, signs of infection and satisfaction with the procedure. The pain level was evaluated using visual analogue scales. Results: Use of the new VCD was technically successful in 98.3%. Adverse events occurred in 4 cases (6.8%), but none of them needed further surgical treatment. All patients had no (93.0%) or low (pain level ≤2; 7.0%) pain due to the use of the VCD. In the follow-up no signs of infection were observed at the puncture sites. All 42 patients who had at least one PEP with MC preferred the sealing via the new VCD.
The use of the tested new VCD was reliable and safe in sealing antegrade puncture sites. Also, the patient satisfaction was excellent.

FIGREF32.text: of inline portal flow to the liver after BRTO of gastric varices in the presence and absence of a TIPS utilizing quantitative digital subtraction angiography (Q-DSA) W.E.A. Saad 1 , C.L. Anderson 1 , M. Kowarschik 2 , U.C. Turba 1 , S. Sabri 1 , A.H. Matsumoto 1 , J.F. Angle 1 ; 1 Vascular and Interventional Radiology, University of Virginia, Charlottesville, VA, United States of America, 2 Imaging & IT Division, Siemens AG, Forchheim, Germany.Purpose: To evaluate portal flow after BRTO in the presence or absence of a TIPS utilizing quantitative-digital subtraction angiography (DSA) and direct flow measurements. Material and Methods: Conventional DSA portography before and after BRTO was performed with post-processing (Q-DSA) on a prototype workstation (iFlow, Siemens). Regions of interest (ROIs) over the entire liver were drawn on pre-and post-BRTO portograms and 1-contrast enhancement slope (CSL), 2-peak contrast density (PCD) and 3-time-density product (AUC) were calculated per ROI. Transcatheter flow measurements were performed in gastrorenal shunts (GRS) that are occluded by BRTO. Results: Seven patients were analyzed utilizing Q-DSA. Four patients underwent BRTO without and three with a patent TIPS.

TABREF8.text: The i.a. therapy includes thrombectomy with the Merci-device as well as augmented i.a. sono-thrombolysis with the EKOS ultrasound/ micro-infusion system. On April 19 this year, it was announced that the National Institute of Neurological Disorders and Stroke decided that the enrolment should be put on hold based on recommendations from the Data and Safety Monitoring Board. The decision was taken because of futility, as there were no differences in clinical outcome between the two patient groups in the study. The subject follow-up will continue and there were no significant safety concerns. Extracted data from the MERCI and Multi-Merci trials as well as several small single centre retrospective studies have shown excellent recanalization rates and 90 days outcome after mechanical thrombectomy for BAO. In comparison with the generally bad revascularization rates and 90 days outcome after i.v. as well as i.a. thrombolysis, a strategy with mechanical thrombectomy as a first line treatment for BAO may be considered. Future Ischemic stroke is a common disease in the industrialized world that mostly affects older people. With an ageing population, a steady increase of stroke patients can probably be expected. TABREF35.text: . Thus, alternative options to vena cava interruption are available in patients with recurrent venous thromboembolism. There is only one randomized controlled trial evaluating vena cava interruption in patients with proximal deep vein thrombosis who are given anticoagulant treatment. In this study, vena cava interruption is associated with an initial decrease in recurrent pulmonary embolism, but with a late increase in the risk of recurrent venous thrombosis when anticoagulant treatment is discontinued 1 . The risk of recurrent venous thromboembolism and overall mortality were not decreased in patients with vena cava filters. International guidelines recommend against the use of an inferior vena cava filter with a grade 1B 2 . New retrievable filters may decrease the risk of initial recurrent venous thromboembolism without increasing the risk of late recurrent venous thromboembolism, but this is not yet confirmed. TABREF38.text: ). However, modern regimens (combining systemic 5-FU with oxaliplatin, irinotecan or both) can obtain ORR similar to those observed with HAI of 5-FU or FUDR. Actually, the ORR reported are about 40-45% with FOLFOX (5-FU + oxaliplatin) or FOLFIRI (5-FU + irinotecan) and up to 66% with FOLFOXIRI regimen). OS for patients with unresectable hepatic metastases is about 17-20 months with FOLFOX or FOLFIRI and 23 months with FOLFOXIRI. These good results have challenged the benefit of the intra-arterial route, especially as the HAI alone cannot guarantee therapeutic activity against occult extra-hepatic disease, which can only be treated through the systemic route. Very high drug concentration can be obtained at the site of embolization with minimal systemic passage.Disclosure: Work supported by Biocompatibles UK X-ray induced DNA double-strand breaks in children undergoing flat-panel CT during cardiovascular interventions M.A. Kuefner 1 , M. Brand 1 , C. Engert 1 , M. Sommer 1 , M. Glöckler 2 , M. Uder 1 ; 1 Department of Radiology, University of Erlangen, Erlangen, Germany, 2 Kinderklinik, University of Erlangen, Erlangen, Germany.Purpose: Flat-panel CT enables CT-like cross-sectional imaging by rotation of the detector around the patient's body and has gained increasing relevance in interventional cardiology and radiology during the past years. The purpose of this study was to evaluate X-ray induced DNA double-strand breaks (DSBs) in blood lymphocytes of children undergoing flat-panel CT during cardiovascular interventions. Material and Methods: 28 patients (age 2 months-21 years) were enrolled. Blood samples were obtained before and 5 minutes after flat-panel CT. Lymphocytes were isolated, stained with an antibody specific for the phosphorylated histone variant γ-H2AX and a fluorescent secondary antibody and foci representing distinct DSBs were quantified using fluorescence microscopy. The amount of CT-induced DSBs was calculated by subtracting pre-CT from post-CT levels. Dose area product was registered as provided by the patient protocol. Results: DSB values ranged from 0.061 to 0.293/cell (median 0.109/ cell) before and from 0.077 to 0.361/cell (median 0.143/cell) after flatpanel CT. The median CT-induced increase of 0.034/cell was statistically significant (p<0.0001). DAP ranged from 39 to 1071 mGy*m2 (median 129 mGy*m2) and showed a weak correlation with the number of CT-induced DSB (Spearman r=0.3228). Conclusion: In all of the patients a slight but significant increase of DSBs was detectable after flat-panel CT. CT-induced DSBs depend on the delivered dose. In conclusion, γ-H2AX immunofluorescence microscopy is a valid method to detect distinct DNA damages even after rather low diagnostic doses and can be used as a measure of biological radiation effects.

TABREF111.text: A.Fohlen  1  , S.H. Ghegediban 2 , J. Namur 2 , A. Laurent 3 , M. Wassef 4 , J.-P. Pelage 1 ; 1 Department of Radiology, University Hospital and Medical Center, Caen, France, 2 R&D, Archimmed, Jouy-en-Josas, France, 3 Interventional Neuroradiology, APHP Hopital Lariboisière, Paris, France, 4 Pathology, APHP Hopital Lariboisière, Paris, France.Purpose: To compare the mechanism of occlusion of hydrocoils and fibered coils in angiography and histology in a sheep model of peripheral embolization. Material and Methods: Six sheep had bilateral embolization of the internal iliac and renal arteries using hydrocoils or fibered coils. Renal and internal iliac arteries were embolized using detachable 0.018 and pushable 0.035 coils, respectively. The number of coils and time to complete occlusion were recorded. Three animals were sacrificed after 24 hours and 3 after 7 days. The mechanism of occlusion was evaluated at pathology: percentage of the lumen occluded by the embolic and thrombus, presence of inflammatory cells. Results: The number of coils and time required to achieve vascular occlusion were not different between hydrocoils and fiberered coils. At 7 days, 75% of iliac arteries embolized with hydrocoils were occluded at angiography versus 67% of those embolized with fiberered coils (NS). Recanalization of the renal artery was observed in both groups. For fibered coils, thrombus accounted for 69% of the occlusion versus 42% for hydrocoils (p=0.005). Around 3% the embolus surface was occupied by fibers for fibered coils versus 16% by hydrogel for hydrocoils. The surface of platinum bars was higher for hydrocoils (42%) than fibered coils (31%) (p=0.05). There was a trend towards more inflammatory cells observed with fibered coils than with hydrocoils (71% vs. 30%). Conclusion: The percentage of thrombus was significantly less with hydrocoils as compared with fibered coils. Markedly lower inflammatory cell response was seen with hydrocoils. Both differences may translate into less long-term recanalization.Disclosure: Consultant and research grants Merit medical, Cook and TerumoSafety and efficacy of the pREset mechanical thrombectomy device for the treatment of cerebral embolic stroke: experience in 78 patients W.Kurre  1 , M. TABREF112.text: Material and Methods: 128 elderly (≥70 years) and 197 younger (<70 years) consecutive patients with HCC who received 90Y-resin microspheres (SIR-Spheres; Sirtex Medical) between 09/2003 and 12/2009 were assessed. Results: The mean age of the elderly and younger cohorts was 74.3 (range: 70-87) years and 58.1 (range: 22-69.8) years, respectively. Both the elderly and younger cohorts had a similar proportion of patients with baseline total bilirubin >1.5 mg/dL (13.3% vs. 19.5%), Child-Pugh class A (85.2% vs. 80.7%), underlying cirrhosis (81.3% vs. 76.6%) and ECOG performance status 0-1 (89.8% vs. 86.2%), respectively. Many had advanced BCLC stage C disease (56.3% vs. 56.3%) invading both lobes (51.2% vs. 54.3%), although more elderly received segmental treatment (10.9% vs. 5.1%; p=0.054). Median overall survival [95% CI; months] did not deteriorate with advancing age(14.5 [10.6-16.8] vs. 12.8 [10.8-17.9]; p=0.942), nor advancing (BCLC stage) disease: early(23.7 [15.1-38.1] vs. 27.4 (19.4-46.8]), intermediate stage(16.9 [10.6-not reached]  vs.

TABREF114.text: M.C. Burgmans1  , Y.H. Kao 2 , F.G. Irani 1 , E.D. Leslee 1 , T.K.B. Teo 1 , T.N. Yeow 1 , M. Taneja 1 , A.E.H. Tan 2 , A.S.W. Goh 2 , P.K. Chow 3 , B.S. Tan 1 , K.H. Tay 1 , R. Lo 1 ;1 Diagnostic Radiology, Singapore General Hospital, Singapore, Singapore, 2 Nuclear Medicine and PET, Singapore General Hospital, Singapore, Singapore,3  Surgery, Singapore General Hospital, Singapore, Singapore.Purpose: To evaluate the feasibility and safety of radioembolization using yttrium-90 (Y-90) resin microspheres through the inferior phrenic artery (IPA). Material and Methods: Retrospective analysis of 108 patients referred for radioembolization to treat unresectable primary (n=103) or secondary (n=5) liver malignancy. DSA, catheter-directed computer tomography angiography (CCTA) and technetium-99m macroaggregated albumin (Tc-99m MAA) SPECT/CT were used to plan treatment and to prevent extra-hepatic deposition. Y-90 imaging of microsphere biodistribution (bremsstrahlung; Y-90 pair production PET) was performed 1 day post-radioembolization. Follow-up was performed using clinical and biochemical tests and cross-sectional imaging with CT or MRI. Results: In 37.0% (n=40) of patients one or more parasitized extrahepatic arteries (PEAs) were detected. Of all patients with PEAs, 62.5% (n=25) had tumor supply through one or both IPAs. Of the patients with IPA supply, 20% (n=5) were treated with infusion of Y-90 into the right IPA. Reasons for disqualifying patients for direct infusion into the IPA were as following: <10% tumor supply (n=11), failed catheterization of IPA (n=3), arterio-portovenous shunt (n=2), failed identification of IPA at time of pre-treatment angiography (n=1), and gastric or esophageal enhancement on CCTA (n=3). In all 5 patients with direct infusion of spheres into the IPA, technical success was demonstrated on Y-90 imaging, without extrahepatic activity. No adverse events related to IPA radioembolization occurred at mean follow-up of 4.5 months (range 2.2-10.1). Conclusion: Delivery of Y-90 microspheres through the right IPA is feasible and safe in selected patients with use of CCTA in addition to DSA and Tc-99m MAA SPECT/CT.Single-center experience with glass-based Yttrium 90 embolization in neuroendocrine liver metastasesB. Arslan 1 , A. Sardari 2 , R. Shridhar 3 , J. Sweeney 2 , B. Biebel 2 , J. Choi 2 ; 1 Radiology, Rush University Medical Center, Chicago, IL, United States of America, 2 Radiology, Moffitt Cancer Center, Tampa, FL, United States of America, 3 Radiation Oncology, Moffitt Cancer Center, Tampa, FL, United States of America.Purpose: To evaluate glass-based Yttrium 90 (Y90) radioembolization in management of neuroendocrine tumors (NET). Specifically to assess toxicities and short-term imaging response. Material and Methods: Retrospective review of all patients who had neuroendocrine metastases to the liver that underwent radioembolization with Y-90 was performed. Electronic patient charts were reviewed to analyze demographics, radiation dosimetry, clinical findings, laboratory data, and imaging findings. Toxicities and side effects reported during the first 3 months of the procedures were identified from clinical notes. Short-term imaging response was assessed using EASL and modified RECIST criteria by reviewing latest imaging study in comparison with pre-treatment studies. Results: A total of 48 patients received 88 radioembolizations between December 2009 and May 2011. 34 patients had adequate follow-up. A total of 60 lobar and segmental radioembolizations were performed in 34 patients. There were 18 males and 16 females with a median age of 61 y/o (43 to 80 y/o). The radiation dose ranged from 74.9 Gy to 347.1 Gy with an average of 150.9 Gy. 22 patients (65%) complained of fatigue. 15 (44%) right-sided abdominal pain and 8 (24%) noted weight loss ranging from 3.5 kg to 11kg. Seven (21%) patients had nausea, but none experienced vomiting. There was no mortality. Response assessment was made per each lobe/ segment treated and average duration for follow-up was 8 months. There were 82.0 % partial response, 10.3 % stable disease, and 7.7 % progression. Conclusion: Glass-based Y90 radioembolization has low toxicity and good imaging response in management of NET metastases to liver.Midterm results of endovascular stent-graft placement for ureteroarterial fistulasT. Okada 1 , M. Yamaguchi 1 , Y. Nomura 2 , K. Uotani 3 , N. Miyamoto 4 , R. Kawasaki 4 , Y. Okita 2 , K. Sugimura 1 , K. Sugimoto 1 ; 1 Department of Radiology and Center for Endovascular Therapy, Kobe University Hospital, Kobe, Japan, 2 Department of Cardiovascular Surgery, Kobe University Hospital, Kobe, Japan,3  Radiology, Tenri Hospital, Tenri, Japan, 4 Department of Radiology, Hyogo Brain and Heart Center at Himeji, Himeji, Japan.

TABREF115.text: At a mean follow-up of 491 days (range 37-1049), four patients (40%) had recurrent hematouria: one underwent secondary stent-graft placement, one had surgical reconstruction and two received supportive care until death. UAF-related recurrence rate is 23.8% and 59.4%, all cause mortality rate is 33.3% and 50% at 1 and 2 years, respectively. Conclusion: Endovascular stent-graft replacement for UAFs is efficacious to manage the acute event; however, the recurrence rate remains high. A further study of long-term results in larger number of patients is necessary.Treatment of iatrogenic brachiocephalic arterial catheterization injuriesS.Annambhotla, M.K. Eskandari, S. Resnick, M.D. Morasch,  H.E. Rodriguez;   Vascular Surgery, Northwestern University, Chicago, IL, United States of America.Purpose: Central venous catheterization is one of the most common procedures performed in a hospital setting. Infrequently, iatrogenic injury to anatomically associated brachiocephalic arteries can present a challenging dilemma. Removal can be accomplished by pulling the catheter with manual pressure; however, if the catheter is lower in the circulation within the subclavian or innominate vessel and/or has been present for a longer period of time, the location can make removal difficult and can result in stroke from embolic phenomenon. We report a 3-year experience with treatment of iatrogenic arterial injuries including pseudoaneurysms and AV fistulas.Material and Methods: Retrospective chart review revealed 11 patients that matched inclusion criteria. Selected patients had iatrogenic injury to the carotid, subclavian, or innominate arteries from misplaced venous access not amenable to simple removal with manual compression. Four patients developed pseudoaneurysm and/or AV fistula of the injured vessel. Results: Endovascular therapy was instituted in 7 cases with two resulting in eventual open repair. Covered stent graft was used in 3 patients and three patients were successfully treated with percutaneous closure devices. Multiple embolization attempts of a large innominate AV fistula required conversion to open sternotomy for definitive repair. Five patients required open repair. One of the 11 cases reviewed developed stroke from embolic phenomenon. No deaths were reported. Conclusion: Brachiocephalic arterial injuries from misplaced venous access can be challenging. The location and risk of stroke prevent simple removal. In most cases, applying endovascular techniques can be successful. However, more complex cases may require definitive open repair. UK popliteal artery aneurysm stent graft study S.D. Goode, T.J. Cleveland, P.A. Gaines, for the Popliteal Study Investigators; Sheffield Vascular Institute, Northern General Hospital, Sheffield, United Kingdom.Purpose: Popliteal artery aneurysms (PAA) are the most common peripheral arterial aneurysms. It is important to recognise these aneurysms because if left untreated they can lead to thrombosis and embolisation to the leg with amputation rates reported of up to 40%. The current gold standard treatment is open surgery, but endovascular techniques are becoming more widely available and used. The aim of this work was to perform a multicentre review of popliteal stent graft use around the UK. Material and Methods: Ten leading UK endovascular centres were contacted to assess their use of endovascular treatments of PAA. A proforma was developed for data collection assessing presentation, aneurysm imaging features and procedural details along with follow-up imaging. This was sent to these centres for data collection. Results: Data on 55 PAA was obtained from 01.2007-02.2011 from 7 UK centres. Mean age was 74 years (Range 62-92), with a male preponderance of 90%. 74% of stents used were Viabahn, 18% Haemobahn, 4% MARS, 2% Fluency and Atrium. Technical success was achieved in 98%. Complications included endoleak (n=4), distal embolisation (n=3) and groin haematoma (n=1). Primary and secondary patency rates at 6months and 1year were 94, 89% and 100%, 95% respectively. Conclusion: Popliteal stent grafting is a relatively new technique, but has the potential to significantly alter and improve the management of patients with PAA. Our dataset represents the largest study of this procedure in the UK and we have shown very encouraging short-term results for our cohort of patients. There is considerable disparity as to endovascular treatment of PAA across the UK.

TABREF116.text: A.G.Schwindt, J.F. Schäfers, G. Torsello;  Vascular and Endovascular Surgery, St. Franziskus-Hospital,  Muenster, Germany.    Purpose: To evaluate the first cohort of patients treated using the novel optical coherence tomography (OCT)-guided Ocelot catheter (Avinger, Inc., Redwood City, CA) at our institution. The catheter provides physicians with real-time OCT imaging whilst crossing peripheral arterial chronic total occlusions (CTOs). Material and Methods: All patients treated between 10/2011 and 01/2012 with the Ocelot catheter were analyzed. All treated lesions were SFA CTOs. Once engaged, OCT images and angiography enabled intraluminal crossing and revascularization as confirmed by distal guidewire placement. Demographics for 30 Patients were documented. 2 (6,6%) patients had PAOD Rutherford II, 18 (60%) Rutherford III, 2 (6,6%) Rutherford IV and 8 (26,6%) Rutherford V. Mean lesion length was 194.4 mm (50-400), mean fluoro time26.7  min (11-50), and mean contrast used was 135.43 cc (70-230). The mean crossing time of the ocelot catheter was 15.72 min. Results: The majority of CTOs (26 (86.6%)) were successfully crossed with the catheter and a guidewire was placed distal of the lesion. In 4 (13.3%) cases recanalization of the SFA could not be achieved. In 2 of the 26 crossings (7.6%) an additional Re-Entry Device was used for distal guidewire placement. Conclusion: The OCT-guided Ocelot provides a new visualization for crossing peripheral arterial CTOs. OCT guidance enabled a high rate of success and safety. Additionally, significant reductions in procedural time and contrast volumes were documented when compared with similar non-OCT guided crossing techniques. Disclosure: J Schäfers receives an unrestricted educational grant from Avinger Inc.Transradial access for above the knee angioplastyR. Lorenzoni, G. Lorenzoni, M. Lazzari, F. Bovenzi;Cardiology Department, Ospedale Campo di Marte, Lucca, Italy.Purpose: Lower extremity arteries' angioplasty is usually done by transfemoral access which is known to have a significant risk of complications. Transradial access (TRA) appears safer than transfemoral access for coronary interventions. The purpose of this study was to evaluate the feasibility and safety of TRA for above the knee (ATK) angioplasty. Material and Methods: Fifty four patients (11 females, mean age 73 years, range 55-90 years; 14 patients symptomatic for critical limb ischemia, 40 for claudication) underwent ATK angioplasty by left (n=40) or right (n=14) TRA. Results: A total of 81 lesions were addressed; 49 stents were positioned in 38 patients with an overall success rate of 83%, with a success rate of 43% for occlusions and of 98% for stenosis. The overall success rate for the 39 suprainguinal lesions was 85%, (success rate 55% for occlusions and 96% for stenosis). The overall success rate for the 42 infrainguinal lesions was 81%, (success rate 33% for occlusions and 100% for stenosis). Success rate was higher for stenotic versus occlusive lesions (p<0.01); no differences in success rate was detected for suprainguinal versus infrainguinal lesions (p=NS). No hemorrhagic complications or local complications needing surgery were observed in any patient. Conclusion: TRA can represent a feasible and safe alternative for ATK angioplasty in case of difficult femoral access, especially in patients with non-occlusive lesions.

TABREF117.text: M.J. Garcia;Interventional Radiology, Christiana Care Health, Newark, DE, United States of America.Purpose: To report registry data in which deep vein thrombosis in lower and upper extremities were treated with rheolytic thrombectomy. Material and Methods: A 2-phase ongoing voluntary registry of the MEDRAD Angiojet catheter used in the treatment of upper and lower extremity DVT was examined. Electronic data capture case report forms were filled out by clinical site staff capturing patient DVT history, procedural information including adjunctive treatments and adverse events. Phase 1 followed patients to a 3-month follow-up documenting symptomatic improvement. The ongoing phase 2 will follow patients through 12 months. Results: Currently 314 patients (41 centers) have been treated including 191 males and 123 females (mean age 53; range 18 to 87). 37 upper extremity and 270 lower extremity DVT cases were included. 219 patients (70%) reported symptoms of < 14 days. Combination therapy using Power Pulse Spray or Rapid Lysis techniques were used in 86% of cases (263/306). 41% of cases were completed in < 6 hours, 76% of cases were completed in < 24 hours. Substantial or complete lysis was achieved in 96% of all treated vessels. Stent placement was performed in 77 patients (25%). Bleeding complications requiring transfusion occurred in 7/314pts (2%). Three-month follow-up was available for 248/314 (79%) of patients with clinical improvement maintained in 82%. At 200 days post procedure, 73% maintained clinical improvement.Conclusion: Rheolytic thrombectomy combined with adjunctive measures form an effective and safe strategy for comprehensive vascular treatment of DVT. Disclosure: MEDRAD Interventional: PEARL Registry Steering Committee & Honoraria Rapid thrombus resolution using ultrasonic thrombolysis in massive and submassive pulmonary embolism D. Quintana, J.T. Salsamendi, G.A. Mohin; Department of Vascular and Interventional Radiology, University of Miami Miller School of Medicine/Jackson Memorial Hospital, Miami, FL, United States of America.Purpose: New treatment guidelines support use of catheterdirected therapy for both massive and submassive pulmonary embolism (PE). This study examines the safety and effectiveness of ultrasound-accelerated (UA) thrombolysis, for which prompt treatment is warranted to rapidly resolve thrombus and restore Material and Methods: We retrospectively reviewed ten consecutive patients between March 2010 and January 2012. All patients exhibited acute symptoms and computed tomography evidence of large, central PE; one patient developed hemodynamic instability (massive), while others presented with submassive PE (hemodynamic stability with significant right heart strain). Seven patients were followed with post-treatment echocardiography to evaluate right heart dysfunction. Thrombolytic treatment was performed in all patients using the Ekosonic® Endovascular system. Clinical outcomes/complications, pulmonary artery (PA) pressure, and thrombus removal were evaluated. A paired Wilcoxon signed-rank test was performed analyzing pre-and post-treatment PA pressures; p < 0.05 was considered significant. Results: All patients (6 males; 4 females; age 52±14) showed significant angiographic clearance following a mean dose of 18.5±9.6mg tPA infused over 24±11.6hrs. In seven patients, there was statistically significant decrease in pre-and post-treatment PA pressures (55±11.2 to 32.3±6.9; p=0.016; CI 15.2-32.0). All patients improved clinically shortly after treatment onset and there were no major bleeding complications. All patients survived to discharge with a median intensive-care (ICU) stay of 4 days and 12 hospital days. Conclusion: UA-thrombolysis is promising in massive and submassive PE treatment, showing safe, repeatable results. Patients demonstrated rapid symptom resolution, improved thrombus burden, and rapid improvement in right cardiac function, while minimizing bleeding risk and ICU time.Stenting of symptomatic superior vena cava obstruction: 10-year experience from a large UK vascular unitS. Chellamuthu, A.J. Alvi, J.M. Slattery, J.R. Bottomley;Northern General Hospital, Sheffield Vascular Institute, Sheffield, United Kingdom.Purpose: To review SVC Stenting, undertaken at a large UK vascular unit. To compare results against published data and outcomes and to offer guidance to referring clinicians about the indications for referral and subsequent patient management. Material and Methods: Retrospective review of radiology reports of patients who had SVC stenting from June 1999 to December 2009 was undertaken. Age, sex, indications, type and size of stent, pre and post dilatation, complications, outcome and survival rates were all reviewed. Results: 56 patients aged from 21 to 84 years underwent catheter venography with a view to SVC stenting. Eight patients were referred for benign causes and 38 for malignant causes of which 30 were for primary lung cancer. 53 patients had an attempt at SVC stent placement and three did not (Two patients had no SVC obstruction and one patient had right atrial involvement). Immediate technical success of stenting was 96%. Two complications included stent migration into RA and stent slippage requiring deployment in the external iliac vein. Luminex, Sinus XL or Memotherm stents were used. Five patients had pre dilatation and 40 patients had post dilatation. Four patients had reintervention of which two patients had restenting and two patients had balloon angioplasty. All patients with malignancy were dead within 18 months of procedure with 71% dead within 3 months. Conclusion: SVC stenting for SVCO remains a safe and effective minimally invasive treatment often with immediate clinical improvement of distressing symptoms. Our 10-year data mean survival rates of 6 months compares favourably against published mean survival rates of 3 months.Minimally invasive treatment of chronic ilio-femoral venous occlusive diseaseC.W.K.P. Arnoldussen1  , M.A.F. de Wolf 2 , M.W. de Haan 1 , R. de Graaf 1 , C.H.A. Wittens 3 ; 1 Radiology and Interventional Radiology, Maastricht University Medical Centre, Maastricht, Netherlands, 2 Vascular surgery, Maastricht University Medical Centre, Maastricht, Netherlands, 3 Department of general and vascular surgery, Maastricht University Medical Centre, Maastricht, Netherlands.Purpose: As one of the primary etiologies of the post-thrombotic syndrome, chronic venous obstruction is a huge burden on patient quality of life and medical costs. We evaluate the short-and midterm results of endovenous recanalisation by angioplasty and stenting in chronic ilio-femoral deep venous occlusions. Material and Methods: Patients with duplex and MR confirmed iliofemoral/caval-occlusions were treated by endovenous angioplasty and stenting. Patients presenting with recent deep vein thrombosis (<1year) were excluded. Patients treated in 2009/2010 were included retrospectively. From 2011 onward patients were included prospectively. Re-occlusions and other types of treatment failure were evaluated during a maximum-follow-up of 26months by ultrasonography and venography. Results: 62 procedures were performed in 51 patients with an average age of 45 years

TABREF118.text: T.Tanaka  1  , P. Isfort 2 , K. Kichikawa 1 , T. Schmitz-Rode 3 , A.H. Mahnken 4 ; 1 Radiology, Nara Medical University, Kashihara, Japan, 2 Diagnostic Radiology, RWTH-Aachen University, Aachen, Germany, 3 Institute of Applied Medical Engineering, RWTH Aachen University & University Hospital Aachen, Aachen, Germany, 4 Department of Diagnostic and Interventional Radiology, University of Technology, Aachen, Germany.

TABREF119.text: was significantly larger than in Group Ib (2.44±0.52cm; P=0.021), Group IIa (2.51±0.32cm; P=0.048), Group IIb(2.19±0.44cm;  P=0.02)  and Group III (1.91±0.55cm; P<0.001). The volume of ablation in Group Ia (20.97±9.65cm3) was significantly larger than in Group III (8.83±4.73cm3; P=0.008). On histology 40μm microspheres were seen to occlude smaller and more distal arteries than 250μm microspheres. There were no deformations of the spherical shape of the microspheres. Conclusion: Pre-ablation superselective bland-TAE is more effective than post-ablation embolization. Small 40μm microspheres enhance the efficacy of RFA more than larger particles.Carotid stenting with distal protection in high surgical risk patients: one-year results of the ASTI trialanalysed and compared with current literature and existing (inter) national guidelines. Material and Methods: In close cooperation with Dutch Societies of IR (NGIR) and Vascular Surgery a study group was formed. A survey was conducted with focus on peri-procedural anticoagulation. It was sent to all active members of NGIR. Results: Response rate was 70%. CAS was performed by 51 of IR (36%), EVAR by 94% and by 84% of respondents together with vascular surgeon. ASA was continued by almost all (97%), but wide variety existed in the continuation pre-procedural of clopidogrel. Heparin was used by most (95%) but other aspects of use showed a wide variety (dosage, way of administration, measurement of effect). Existing guidelines, including CIRSE SOP, were only partially met. Conclusion: This survey provides an extensive knowledge of current practice of IR and PAI in the Netherlands. The apparent wide variety is consistent with literature over the past 25 years. Existing guidelines are only partially met, but these are also based on a low level of evidence. The need for more uniformity in all aspects of periprocedural anticoagulation during PAI is clear. This should be based on new RCTs, resulting in evidence-based guidelines.Quality improvements in interventional radiology by implementation of an angiography patient experience (APEX) surveyJ.R. Bottomley 1 , Z. Zaitout 2 ; 1 Vascular Surgery, Sheffield Vascular Institute, Northern General Hospital, Sheffield, United Kingdom, 2 Medical Imaging with Medical Physics, Sheffield Teaching Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust, Sheffield, United Kingdom.

TABREF120.text: Yella, S.M.Gregory, C. Gonzalez-Junyent, G.S. Goh, G.J. Munneke,  L. Ratnam, M. Gonsalves;  Department of Radiology, St. George's Hospital, London, United  Kingdom.    Purpose: To identify the frequency of adverse events associated with the use of conscious sedation in interventional radiology (IR), and to determine risk factors associated with adverse outcomes. Material and Methods: Single-centre, prospective study of patients undergoing conscious sedation for IR procedures. Patient demographics, ASA, procedure class (vascular/ hepatobiliary/ urological/ gastrointestinal) dose of analgesia and sedative, modified observer assessment of sedation score (MOASS), pain score and adverse incidents were recorded. Adverse incidents were classified as either minor or major. Statistical analysis was performed using two-tailed Chi2 or Fisher's exact test. Results: 104 cases (urological 30% (31/104), hepatobiliary 29% (30/104), gastrointestinal 18% (19/104) and vascular 22% (23/104) were performed over a 5-month period. Mean dose of midazolam and fentanyl was 2.5mg and 55,2mcg, respectively. Overall adverse incident rate was 18% (19/104). Rate of minor and major adverse incidents were 15% (16/104) and 3% (3/104), respectively. Minor incidents were predominantly respiratory in nature. All major adverse incidents were related to patient agitation (MOASS=6) resulting in abandonment of the procedure. Statistically significant associations with adverse incidents are age >80 (P<0.013) and MOASS <or=3 (P<0.001). Patients undergoing hepatobiliary procedures experienced deeper levels of sedation (P<0.05) and poorer subjective pain control (P<0.014). Conclusion: Conscious sedation during interventional radiology procedures is safe. In our cohort of patients, increasing age and depth of sedation were statistically significant associations with adverse incidents. Minor adverse incidents were not infrequent, but easily treated with no lasting impact on patient outcome. Major adverse outcomes were uncommon.Urgent stroke treatment: single-centre data on the pilot Catalan experience R. Barranco Pons 1 , M.A. de Miquel Miquel 2 ; 1 Radiology, L'Hospitalet de Llobregat, Hospital de Bellvitge, Barcelona, Spain, 2 Neurointerventional Radiology, Hospital de Bellvitge, Barcelona, Spain.

TABREF121.text: : From this pilot experience begun on April 2010, results of the first two years of setting show that, for a population of two million people, 70 patients/year are found to be tributary of intraarterial thrombectomy. The ratio of strokes initially sent from the peripheral hospitals and finally treated by thrombectomy has been found to be around 1/3. Conclusion: In our experience, dealing with stroke treatment, at least 35 patients in every million people can be candidates for intraarterial thrombectomy. An organized network, patient transportation and a refined stroke diagnostic process are crucial to be combined with the work of vascular neurologists and interventional neuroradiologists.FDG-PET-CT and whole-body MRI for triage in patients planned for radioembolisation therapy G.P. Schmidt 1 , P.M. Paprottka 1 , T.F. Jakobs 2 , R.-T. Hoffmann 3 , A. Baur-Melnyk 1 , K. Nikolaou 1 , M.F. Reiser 1 , C. Rist 1 ; 1 Institute for Clinical Radiology, University Hospitals Munich-Grosshadern, Munich, Germany, 2 Department of Radiology, Krankenhaus der Barmherzigen Brüder München, Munich, Germany, 3 Inst. u. Pk. f. Radiologische Diagnostik, Medizinische Fakultät Carl-Gustav-Carus, TU Dresden, Dresden, Germany.Purpose: The purpose was to evaluate the potential of FDG-PET-CT and whole-body MRI (WB-MRI) as diagnostic triage methods for patients planned for radioembolisation of metastatic liver disease. Material and Methods: 135 patients with multifocal liver metastases were evaluated for potential palliative therapy with radioembolisation (RE) using 90-Yttrium microspheres. All patients were examined consecutively with FDG-PET-CT and WB-MRI for exclusion of relevant extra-hepatic tumor manifestations. All patients underwent 99mTc-albumine angiography followed by scintigraphy to exclude significant hepato-pulmonary shunting. Results: Of 135 included patients 56% were eligible and received RE, while 44% could not be treated. In 91% the exclusion criteria was diagnosis of significant extra-hepatic metastatic disease. In 85% exclusion diagnosis was made concordantly by both FDG-PET-CT and WB-MRI, in 9% diagnosis was provided by PET-CT, and in 6% by WB-MRI alone. Patient-based sensitivity for detection of extrahepatic disease was 94% for PET-CT and 91% for WB-MRI. Falsepositive diagnosis of extrahepatic disease leading to exclusion for RE was made in 2% of patients, in one patient by PET-CT and in one patient by WB-MRI alone. Overall, specificity for inclusion of RE by combining both modalities was 99%. In 9% of patients angiographic diagnosis made RE impossible, and in 7% solely the angiographic findings were decisive. Conclusion: Both FDG-PET-CT and WB-MRI are efficient diagnostic triage methods for patients planned for radioembolisation of liver metastases. Overall, FDG-PET-CT shows higher diagnostic accuracy compared with WB-MRI and may be used as a standalone examination. In combination, both modalities exhibited high sensitivity for the diagnosis of extra-hepatic tumor manifestations and result in high specificity.

TABREF122.text: T.Aramaki  1  , M. Moriguchi 1 , E. Bekku 1 , K. Asakura 1 , M. Endo 1 , K. Yoshimura 2 ; 1 Div. of Diagnostic Radiology, Shizuoka Cancer Center, Shizuoka, Japan, 2 Translational Research, Kyoto University Hospital, Kyoto, Japan.

TABREF123.text: received 2.5 hours of bed rest. If no bleeding or hematomas were observed in this group, the final group (level 3) received 2 hours of bed rest. If bleeding or hematomas were observed after bed rest in any patient, this study would be terminated, and the bed rest duration of the previous level would be taken as the optimal duration. Each group included 105 patients. Results: Between November 2010 and September 2011, 105 patients were enrolled in level 1 of this study. Eight patients were excluded because bed rest did not end at the appropriate time. In the remaining 97 patients, no bleeding or hematomas were observed. Conclusion: The duration of bed rest required after IR via the femoral artery using 3-French sheath introducer systems is less than 3 hours. Level 2 of this study is currently ongoing.Uterine artery embolisation for symptomatic uterine fibroids: 10-year clinical follow-up M. de Kiefte, P.N.M.Lohle, A.J. Smeets;  Radiology, St. Elisabeth Hospital, Tilburg, Netherlands.    Purpose: Based on short-and mid-term results uterine artery embolisation (UAE) is accepted as treatment for symptomatic uterine fibroids. However, long-term follow-up results after UAE are unknown. We report the 10-year follow-up results after UAE. Material and Methods: To assess the clinical outcome with 10-year follow-up we questioned 40 consecutive women who have been embolized for symptomatic uterine fibroids in the past (at the date of submission, with the goal of at least 70). UAE treatment failure was defined by major subsequent therapy (hysterectomy, myomectomy and a second UAE) and/or no symptom relief (sustained or recurrent pain, bulk and bleeding symptoms). For statistical analysis we used SPSS and a proportional cox hazard analysis to analyse risk factors for failure. Results: We were able to contact 40 patients who met our inclusion criteria. Of these patients 15 (38%) needed to undergo a major additional intervention (hysterectomies in 9, myomectomies in 2, repeat UAE in 4). None of the other patients had symptoms related to uterine fibroids. No significant risk factors were found. The hazard ratio for age was 0.78 p=0.052 with a mean age of 43 years at UAE.Conclusion:Based on long-term results, UAE confirms to be a successful minimal invasive therapy for symptomatic uterine fibroids. The vast majority (78%) of women show durable (10 years) symptom relief with preservation of the uterus. There is a trend for higher age to have a better clinical outcome 10 years after UAE for symptomatic uterine fibroids.Intravenous administration of Ultrasound Contrast Media (CEUS) during ultrasound-guided high-intensity focused ultrasound (USgHIFU) ablation for uterine fibroids L.Monfardini  1  , P. Della Vigna 1 , G. Bonomo 1 , D. Origgi 2 , M. Krokidis 3 , F. Orsi 1 ; 1 Interventional Radiology Unit, European Institute of Oncology, Milan, Italy, 2 Department of Medical Physics, European Institute of Oncology, milan, Italy, 3 Department of Radiology, Guys and St Thomas Hospitals, London, United Kingdom.Purpose:The study was designed to assess effectiveness and safety of intraprocedural i.v. contrast-enhanced ultrasound (CEUS) on USgHIFU ablation for the treatment of uterine fibroids. Material and Methods: Thirty-three patients with a total of 41 symptomatic uterine fibroids in reproductive age were randomly divided into two groups before USgHIFU ablation: A (22 fibroids) and B (19 fibroids). During USgHIFU sessions, micro-bubble contrast agent (SonoVue, Bracco, Italy) was administered 30 min before, during and 30 min after USgHIFU-ablation in group A. Intraprocedural CEUS led to further HIFU sonications if residual vascularisation was detected, whereas in group B USgHIFU was carried on with plain US and CEUS was performed at the end of the procedure only, for a final evaluation. Follow-up with MR was performed at 1, 3, 6 and 12 months. Technical success, efficacy and complication rates were compared between the two groups. Symptomatic relief and quality of life improvement were also assessed. Results: Technical success was 100% in all patients and there was no significant difference in the complication rate between groups A and B. Ablation in group A patients (with intraprocedural CEUS) was more effective (p<0.05) with a lower reintervention rate and a more significant volume reduction at 12 months. However, long-term symptom relief was also improved in group B. Conclusion: CEUS is a useful tool in the assessment of therapeutic response during HIFU ablation. Intravenous administration of microbubbles is a safe, effective procedure and seems to enhance HIFU efficacy for uterine fibroids.Incomplete uterine fibroid embolization for patients who want to conceive J.M. Pisco, M. Duarte, T. Bilhim, H. Rio Tinto, L. Fernandes, J.A. Pereira; Interventional Radiology, Saint Louis Hospital, Lisbon, Portugal.Purpose: To evaluate pregnancy outcome following incomplete uterine fibroid embolization. Material and Methods: Uterine fibroid embolization (UFE) was performed in 158 patients who could not get a successful pregnancy before embolization and wanted to conceive. Partial embolization was performed blocking only the small vessels. Polyvinyl alcohol (PVA) particles were used as embolic agent. Results: From the 158 patients, 85 (53.8%) had spontaneous pregnancies without any medically assisted reproduction technique. Their age ranged from 22 to 43 years (mean 37.1 years). There are 75 finished pregnancies: 63 successful life births (84%), 9 spontaneous abortions (12.1%), 2 induced abortion, 1 stillbirth at 36 weeks and 10 ongoing pregnancies. The procedure was repeated in 6 patients with incomplete fibroid ischemia, and 3 of them had spontaneous abortion after first UFE. There were 5 preterm gestations (7.9%), 2 cases of placenta previa (3.2%), 5 low birth weights (7.9%) and 39 cesarean sections (61.9%). Conclusion: Partial uterine fibroid embolization is a safe and efficient procedure with low morbidity, high rate of spontaneous pregnancies (53.8%) and live birth (84%).Disclosure: Cook MedicalUterine fibroid embolization after myomectomyN.-K. Kabutey 1 , S. Deso 2 , M. Dawoud 1 , S. Baer 3 , D. Kim 1 ; 1 Radiology, Boston University School of Medicine, Boston, MA, United States of America, 2 Radiology, Stanford University, Palo Alto, CA, United States of America, 3 Obstetrics/Gynecology, Harvard Vanguard Medical Associates, Boston, MA, United States of America.Purpose: To study the clinical effectiveness and examine the demographic factors of patients that have undergone a uterine fibroid embolization (UFE) after a surgical myomectomy. Material and Methods: Retrospective clinical database analysis of 1257 patients collected over a 13-year time period. One hundred one patients underwent a myomectomy procedure prior to uterine fibroid embolization. All the patients were examined and referred by their private gynecologist for uterine fibroid embolization. Available pre-procedural and follow-up information was tabulated and examined. Results: One hundred one (8.0%) of the 1257 patients underwent bilateral UFE after surgical myomectomy. The mean age of the patients at the time of initial UFE was 43.3, with a range of 25-54 years. Prior to UFE, 56 patients (55.5%) were experiencing 3 or more symptoms. At 6-month follow-up, only 4 (4.0%) patients continued to complain of multiple symptoms. No procedural complications were recorded for patients undergoing UFE after uterine artery embolization. Technical success rate was 100%. Conclusion: UFE is an excellent treatment option for patients that have had a prior surgical myomectomy. UFE has a high procedural success and a low complication rate for patients that have had a surgical myomectomy prior to UFE.Fallopian tube recanalization: a seasoned solution to a salient problem, a single institution reviewPurpose: To evaluate whole-liver treatment impacts on the safety, tolerability and survival following radioembolization. Material and Methods: 325 patients received 90Y-resin microspheres (SIR-Spheres; Sirtex Medical) between September 2003 and December 2009 at 8 European centres. Patients were mostly Child-Pugh class A (82.5%), had underlying cirrhosis (78.5%), but many had bilobar disease (53.1%) and/or portal vein occlusion (23.3%). Results: Most patients received single-session (>95%) wholeliver (47.7%) or right-lobe administration (36.3%), with few leftlobe (8.6%) or selective segmental treatments (7.4%). Delivered median activity(1.7 vs. 1.2 GBq; p=0.153) and target liver volume (1757 vs. 400 mL; p<0.001) were greater with whole-liver than segmental treatment. Patients with early (stage A) vs. advanced (stage C) HCC were more likely to receive segmental treatment (45.8% vs. 33.3%) than left-lobe (32.1% vs. 42.9%), right-lobe(14.4% vs. 50.8%)   or whole-liver (9.7% vs. 66.5%) treatment (p<0.001). Median survivals [95%CI] for patients treated with segmental, left-lobe, right-lobe and whole-liver approaches were 23.7 [9.0-not reached],13.8 [8.7-27.4],  13.1 [10.2-18.4] and 12.4 [10.4-15.4] months (p=0.176). No treatment approach further compromised liver function (bilirubin, albumin, ALT, INR or platelets) as measured by an increase in CTCAE grade >3 from baseline to 3 months (p>0.05). Transient fatigue was more frequent with whole-liver than lobar/segmental treatment (p<0.001). The incidence of GI ulcers was 3.7% (overall) and 5.8% (whole-liver). Conclusion: Radioembolization was tailored to burden of HCC. Liver function was not further compromised irrespective of the hepatic volume treated. Disease stage, rather than treatment approach, was the main driver of survival.included pregnancies 24%, continuing treatment 40%, discontinued treatment 22%. Questionnaire results included adequate pre-procedure information, 96%; stressful procedure, 61% (75% would have a repeat procedure); mild pain, 43% (92% <24hr); post procedural bleeding, 61% (spotting 94% (94% <3days). No infections. Of the 15 pregnancies interventions included normal pressure injection, 13%; moderate pressure injection, 33%; high-pressure injection, 28%; wire cannulation, 13%; and combined wire cannulation and subsequent high-pressure injection, 13%. Conclusion: Fallopian tube recanalization is a simple technique with a high technical success rate and a low complication rate. Belli; Department of Radiology, St George's Hospital, London, United Kingdom.Purpose:We have observed significant rates of uterine artery recanalisation following uterine artery embolization (UAE) with nonspherical PVA (nsPVA). Study aims are as follows: to quantitatively assess uterine artery patency following UAE with nsPVA; to determine risk factors for uterine artery patency; and to assess effect of continued uterine artery patency on outcomes. Material and Methods: Single centre, retrospective study of 50 patients undergoing bilateral UAE for uterine leiomyomata was undertaken. MRI pelvis was performed prior and 6 months post-UAE. Uterine artery patency, uterine and dominant fibroid volume, dominant fibroid percentage infarction, presence of ovarian arterial collaterals with symptom scores and UFS-QOL scores were recorded. Results: 90% of patients demonstrated MRA uterine artery recanalisation (64% bilateral, 26% unilateral) at 6 months. 80% of all dominant fibroids demonstrated >90% infarction. Mean percentage reduction in dominant fibroid volume was 35%

TABREF124.text: , Y.-S.Kim, H.K. Lim, M.W. Lee;  Radiology, Samsung Medical Center, Seoul, Korea.    Purpose: To assess ten-year outcomes of RFA as a first-line therapy of early-stage HCC, with an emphasis on the influence of local tumor progression on overall survival. Material and Methods: From April 1999 to April 2011, 1305 patients (male:female=993:312; mean age, 58.4 years) with 1502 early-stage HCCs (mean size, 2.2cm) were treated with percutaneous RFA as a first-line option. Follow-up period ranged 0.4-146.6 months (median,  33.4 months). We assessed local tumor progression rates and overall survival rates at 5 and10 years, the prognostic factors on local tumor progression, and overall survival rates. Results: The cumulative local tumor progression rates were 27.0% and 36.9% at five and ten years, respectively, for which the only significant risk factor was large tumor size (B=0.543, p<0.001). Cumulative intrahepatic distant and extrahepatic recurrence rates were 73.1% and 88.5% and 19.1% and 38.2% at five and ten years, respectively. Corresponding overall survival rates were 59.7% and 32.3%, respectively. Poor survival was associated with old age (B=0.025, p<0.001), Child-Pugh class B (B=-0.689, p<0.001), large tumor size (B=0.169, p=0.016), absence of intrahepatic distant recurrence (B=-0.270, p=0.030) and presence of extrahepatic recurrence (B=1.125, p<0.001). Occurrence of local tumor progression did not influence overall survival according to univariate or multivariate analysis (p=0.729 and p=0.401, respectively). Conclusion: Ten-year survival outcomes after percutaneous RFA as a first-line therapy of HCC are excellent despite frequent tumor recurrences. Occurrence of local tumor progression does not have a significant influence on overall survival.Role of transarterial chemoembolization as bridging strategy in T2 HCC patients on the waiting listE. Bozzi, I.Bargellini, F. Turini, A. Cicorelli, R. Cioni, C. Bartolozzi;   Diagnostic & Interventional Radiology, University of Pisa, Pisa, Italy.Purpose: To retrospectively evaluate long-term outcomes of T2 stage HCC patients who underwent orthothopic liver transplantation (OLT) after transarterial chemoembolization (TACE), compared with patients transplanted without bridging therapy. Material and Methods: The study included 168 cirrhotic patients (147 males, mean age 55.8 years) with T2 HCC, who underwent OLT from 1996 to 2010. In patients treated by TACE, latest CT examination prior to OLT was reviewed to assess tumor response according to mRECIST. Patients were divided into three groups: A) no bridging therapy; B) complete response (CR) after TACE; C) partial response, stable or progressive disease after TACE. Overall (OS), recurrencefree (RFS) and disease-free (DFS) survivals were calculated by Kaplan-Meyer analysis and compared by log-rank test. Results: Fifty-six patients were in group A, 60 patients in group B and 52 patients in group C; preprocedural data were comparable among groups. Five-year OS, RFS and DFS were 75.2%, 92.7% and 73.2%, respectively. Survivals were significantly higher in group B compared with group C and comparable between group A and B. In tumors > 3cm, DFS censored for peri-operative deaths (n=7) was higher in group B compared with group A (p=0.05). Conclusion: In T2 transplanted patients, CR after pre-operative TACE represents a favorable prognostic indicator for survival and tumor recurrence. TACE may be beneficial for T2 HCC patients with overall tumor size >3cm. the patients received a median radiation dose of 106 Gy (95% CI 64 -139) per treatment. Results: Median overall survival was 7.5 months (95% CI 6.3 -8.8). Predictive factors for shortened overall survival included ECOG performance grade 1 or 2 (P=0.049), INR >1.2 (P=0.010), largest tumor size >5 cm (P=0.012), venous invasion (P=0.035), AFP level at presentation >200 ng/mL (P=0.001), objective tumor response (<0.001), and liver toxicity (P=0.009). Irreversible liver toxicity occurred in 68 patients (39.8%). Predictive factors for liver toxicity included age >65 years (OR 2.87, P=0.028), and INR>1.2 (OR 3.09, P=0.019). Conclusion: Radioembolization Y90 for HCC in patients with HBV infection is associated with suboptimal survival outcome and alarming risk of irreversible liver toxicity. Although identification of predictive factors for overall survival and liver toxicity does help in selecting suitable patients, further studies are required to establish the role of radioembolization Y90 among other transarterial therapies.

Disclosure: Pr Garin is consultant for MDS Nordion.Hybrid procedures for complex thoracic aorta disease U.G.Rossi, S. Seitun, F. Petrocelli, L. Patrone, I. Budaj, C. Ferro;   Radiology and Interventional Radiology, IRCCS San Martino University Hospital -IST -National Institute for Cancer Research, Genoa, Italy.Purpose: To describe our experience with the feasibility, safety, and effectiveness of hybrid procedures for complex thoracic aorta disease.Material and Methods: From March 2004 to November 2011 we treated 46 patients with hybrid techniques (5 in emergency): 20 aortic arch aneurysms, 15 aortic dissections, 7 penetrating ulcers, and 4 intramural hematoma. There were performed 21 transposition of epiaortic vessels, 15 extra-anatomical bypass, 6 surgical procedures of elephant trunk associated with thoracic endoprosthesis and 4 endoprosthesis E-Vita Open. 25 patients were treated in two stages (endovascular procedure within 2 weeks), while the remaining 21 patients in one time. Results: Technical success was achieved in all patients (100%).Mortality at 30 days occurred in 5 patients (11%) due to visceral ischemia, hypokalemia, and MOF. There were no permanent neurological complications. After a mean follow-up of 25 months, the CT angiography control showed a complete remodeling of the treated thoracic aorta in 32 patients. The presence of endoleaks (EL) was observed in 6 patients (13%): two early type 1 EL (spontaneously reversible), three early type 2 EL and one late type 3 EL, that were treated successfully. Conclusion: Hybrid procedures for the treatment of complex thoracic aorta diseases are effective and safe with good results in terms of morbidity and mortality.Acute traumatic rupture of the thoracic aorta. A contemporary, expectant management W.C. Fox 1 , D.J. Komorowski 1 , G.S. Morano 1 , M.K. Sydnor 1 , J. Tisnado 1 , J. Tisnado 2 , D.R. Brinster 3 ; 1 Radiology/Vascular and Interventional, MCV Hospitals/ VCU Medical Center, Richmond, VA, United States of America, 2 Radiology, Hartford General Hospital, Hartford, CT, United States of America, 3 Surgery, MCV Hospitals / VCU Health System, Richmond, VA, United States of America.Purpose: Acute traumatic rupture of thoracic aorta (ATRTA) carries a high M&M, with 86% victims dying at the scene. 10-15% survives initial impact. Only 2% live long enough to develop chronic pseudoaneurysm, if diagnosis is not made and therapy instituted. Established treatment protocols are based on dated literature dictating immediate intervention: emergent open surgical repair, associated with high M&M, which is increased in a trauma setting. Some authors propose meticulous control of blood pressure for monitored delay of open repair in patients with concomitant life-threatening injuries. There is 9% rate of delayed rupture in patients stable upon admission as reason for immediate intervention. With recent advancements in stent-graft technology, we developed a modern treatment strategy emphasizing strict blood pressure control and, urgent rather than emergent, endovascular repair. Material and Methods: Since 2006, we electively delayed repair of ATRTA victims until stable to withstand endovascular or "combined" (open and endovascular) repair, for hours, days and even months with early blood pressure control, ICU monitoring, and a team on standby, if emergent repair necessary.

TABREF127.text: First human study in thoraco-abdominal aortic aneurysms M.C. Henry 1 , I.P. Henry 2 , A. Benjelloun 3 ; 1 Cardiologie, Cabinet de Cardiologie, Nancy, France, 2 Clinique Bois Bernard, Bois Bernard, France, 3 Chirurgie Vasculaire, Clinique Coeur et Vaisseaux, Sale, Morocco.Treatment of complex arch and descending thoracic aortic disease using conformable TAG® stent-graft: single center early resultsPurpose: The Gore conformable TAG © (cTAG) is the new generation of thoracic stent-graft designed for an adaptable fit into the tortuous aorta and for improved landing in the arch, avoiding well-known issues such as "bird beaking". We report our early results. Material and Methods: From July 2011 to January 2012, 41 cTAG devices were deployed in 20 consecutive patients with suitable thoracic aortic pathology. Mean age was 70-years (range 36-83, female=3) .The main motivation for using cTAG was tortuous anatomy, angulated arch and/or small diameter landing zones, where it was felt the low profile, conformable design would have an advantage over other graft devices. Results: 8 emergencies and 12 elective procedures were performed (14 aneurysm, 2 IMH, 1 acute dissection, 1 penetrating aortic ulcer, chronic dissection and transection). Aneurysm diameter range was 25-100mm with mean proximal landing zone of 30mm (range 25-36mm). Average treatment length was 251mm with mean of 2 stents per case. Proximal landing zone anatomy was 0 n=3), and 1 elephant trunk. Technical success was 95%. Complications were 10% (n=1 migration due to technical fault, n=1 TIA with complete recovery). 30-day mortality was 10% (mesenteric ischemia n=1 and multisystem failure with infected aneurysm=1). Conclusion: Our early results show good technical and clinical success with cTAG in patients with challenging anatomies. Long-term data are needed to assess durability and outcome.Purpose: To explore a novel treatment strategy for patients with ascending aortic dissections, but considered unfit for open surgery, we conducted complete endovascular repair on a series of this kind of patients. Material and Methods: From May 2009 to January 2011, fortyone consecutive patients with ascending aortic dissection were treated in our institution. Fifteen patients, who were excluded from open surgery and met inclusion criteria of endovascular procedure, underwent endovascular repair. Results: All the stent-grafts were successfully deployed to the intended location. There were no major complications, and no death in the peri-operative period. The median follow-up time was 22 months, ranging from 12 to 31 months. Except one new dissection in aortic arch was detected three months after the procedure and finally treated by a branched stent-graft, no other complication or death was noted in the follow-up period. Significant enlargements of the true lumen were found at different levels of the thoracic aorta after the endovascular procedure, and diameters of the aorta at the levels of maximal and distal ascending aorta significantly decreased.Conclusion: Pure endovascular repair may become a promising option for patients with ascending aortic dissections and inappropriate for traditional open surgery, and longer observation and larger sample are expected. Treatment of type II endoleaks after endovascular repair of abdominal aortic aneurysm: role of transcaval endoleak embolization R. Gandini, M. Chiocchi, C. Del Giudice, D. Morosetti, A. Chiaravallotti, G. Simonetti; Diagnostic Imaging and Interventional Radiology, IRCCS Policlinico di Tor Vergata, Rome, Italy.Purpose: To describe our 4-year single centre experience in the treatment of type II endoleak using the transcaval endoleak embolization (TCEE).Material and Methods:The study was institutional review board approved. All subjects involved in the study provided written informed consent. From January 2007 to April 2011, 32 patients (26 men and 6 women, mean age 75 ± 5.6 years) underwent to a post-EVAR type II endoleak treatment after a computed tomography angiography diagnosis. A preprocedural angiography through a transfemoral approach was performed to confirm the presence of endoleak. Then a puncture of the aneurysm sac was performed through the inferior cava vein using a trans-jugular porto-systemic shunt kit. Once the aneurysm sac was engaged with a 5 Fr diagnostic catheter a unselective of selective embolization was performed. Complete exclusion of the endoleak was confirmed with invasive sac pressure measurement before withdrawn the catheter. Results: TCEE was successful in 26 patients (100%). 5 (19%) patients underwent an unselective TCEE and 21 (81%) patients a selective TCEE. No major complications were observed intra-and peri-procedurally. 3 patients (12%) treated with unselective embolization presented recurrence of endoleak at 1-year follow-up. 1 patient (4%) needed a surgical aortic abdominal replacement. 2 patients thrombophlebitis at vein puncture site. Conclusion: TCEE is a safe and effective treatment that can be proposed as first line therapy in TAEE failed cases or in complex endoleak, caused by one or multiple feeding vessels.

TABREF128.text: Treatment of benign post-surgery biliary strictures with a 3-fold repeated percutaneous balloon dilatation regimen without long-term indwelling cathetersE.Dhondt, P. Vanlangenhove, L. Defreyne;  Department of Vascular and Interventional Radiology, Ghent  University Hospital, Ghent, Belgium.    Purpose: To determine patency rates of 3-fold repeated percutaneous balloon dilatation in benign biliary strictures. Material and Methods: Patients with benign biliary strictures after surgery were prospectively included to receive a one-week therapy session consisting of a 20-min lasting balloon dilatation on day 1, repeated on day 3 and 5. No catheters were left behind. Technical success was accepted if there was a less than 30% residual stenosis.Primary and secondary patency rates were calculated, as well as cumulative primary and secondary patency rates. Results: N=50 patients underwent N=75 dilatation sessions for strictures after liver transplantation (N=40), liver resection (N=4) or biliary surgery (N=6). N=33 patients underwent one, N=12 two, N=4 three and N=1 six dilatation sessions. Technical success was achieved in 71/75 (94.6%) sessions. Mean primary patency rate was 374 days (SD 363 days). Of N=33 patients treated by one session, N=20 were without event at a mean follow-up of 614 days. Four patients underwent surgery, N=3 retransplantation, N=1 endoscopic stenting and N=2 percutaneous stenting. Three patients died after first dilatation (mean patency 85 days). N=13/17 (76.5%) patients treated with multiple sessions were uneventful until last follow up. Overall secondary patency rate was 593 days (SD 487 days). Cumulative primary patency rate at 6 months was 60%, at 1 year 38% and at 2 years 14%; secondary patency rates were 76%, 58% and 34%, respectively. Conclusion: In benign post-surgery biliary strictures, repeated percutaneous dilatation is effective. As long-term indwelling catheters were avoided, patient's comfort was improved.
